title: RondoDox botnet exploits critical React2Shell flaw
executive_summary: A botnet named RondoDox has been actively exploiting a critical unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability known as React2Shell in React Server Components and Next.js.
The campaign has been ongoing for around nine months, targeting IoT devices and web servers worldwide to deploy malware and cryptominers.
what_happened: Researchers observed the RondoDox botnet abusing the React2Shell vulnerability (CVE-2025-55182, CVSS 10.0) to gain remote code execution on exposed systems.
The botnet campaign progressed through multiple phases from reconnaissance to large-scale automated exploitation.
Once systems are compromised, payloads such as cryptominers, a Mirai variant, and bot loaders are deployed.
who_is_affected: Internet-connected web servers running vulnerable Next.js instances
IoT devices exposed to the internet (e.g., consumer routers, cameras)
attack_flow: Botnet scans internet for systems vulnerable to React2Shell
Unauthenticated exploit of RCE vulnerability on IoT and web servers
Deployment of malware payloads (cryptominers, bot loaders)
Persistence mechanisms installed and competing malware removed
business_impact: Elevated risk of DDoS attacks from botnet networks
Potential service degradation and increased operational costs
risk_reason: Exploitation of a critical unauthenticated remote code execution flaw in widely used frameworks makes a high number of systems vulnerable to automated compromise.
what_usually_goes_wrong: Failure to patch known critical vulnerabilities in a timely manner
Exposure of IoT devices without sufficient network segmentation
Lack of monitoring for unauthorized activity

immediate: Apply patches or updates for Next.js and React Server Components to address the React2Shell vulnerability
Identify and isolate vulnerable devices from public networks
short_term: Deploy Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) to block exploit traffic
Monitor systems for unusual processes or connections
long_term: Segment IoT devices into dedicated VLANs
Implement continuous vulnerability scanning and patch management
Adopt threat intelligence feeds to block known command-and-control IPs

what_this_does_not_mean: Every organization using Next.js is already breached
Patching once solves all IoT security concerns

signs: Unexpected new cron jobs or persistence artifacts
Unusual outbound connections from servers or devices
High CPU usage indicative of cryptomining
alerts: Detection of exploitation attempts targeting React2Shell
Unauthorized remote shells or malware execution
